content.passage: At sunrise, the students gathered by the river with gloves and bags. They worked in small teams and stayed ___[BLANK_1]___ even when the weather became warm. By noon, the riverbank looked much cleaner, and everyone felt ___[BLANK_2]___ of their effort. Their teacher reminded them that small actions can ___[BLANK_3]___ a big difference over time.
sentences: At sunrise, the students gathered by the river with gloves and bags.
They worked in small teams and stayed ___[BLANK_1]___ even when the weather became warm.
By noon, the riverbank looked much cleaner, and everyone felt ___[BLANK_2]___ of their effort.
Their teacher reminded them that small actions can ___[BLANK_3]___ a big difference over time.

blanks.hint: They kept paying attention to the task.
A feeling after doing something good.

hintDependencies.unlockedHint: Because they stayed focused, they felt positive about results.
Feeling proud comes when actions make impact.

rich_json.contextExplanation: In this passage, focused means the students kept their minds on cleaning and did not get distracted.
exampleSentences: Mina stayed focused during her maths revision.
Please stay focused while crossing the road.
The team remained focused until the project was done.
rich_json.mnemonic: FOCUSED = Fewer Outside Clues, Use Sharp Eyes Daily.
rich_json.etymology: From Latin focus, meaning fireplace/hearth; later used as a center point.

commonMistakes.whyWrong: Sleepy describes feeling tired, not paying attention to a task.
commonMistakes.correctTip: If the sentence is about concentration, choose focused.

rich_json.rootAffixNote: -ed shows past form or adjective state in context.

rich_json.contextExplanation: Proud fits because the students achieved something meaningful and felt good about it.
exampleSentences: I felt proud when I helped my classmate.
Her parents were proud of her kindness.
The school was proud of the science fair winners.
rich_json.mnemonic: PROUD = Positive Result, Own it, Understand the joy, Do your best.
rich_json.etymology: From Old French prud/prod, linked to being worthy or valiant.

commonMistakes.whyWrong: Afraid is a fear feeling, opposite of happy achievement feelings.
commonMistakes.correctTip: When success appears in context, proud is often a better fit.

rich_json.contextExplanation: In 'make a difference', make means to cause or create an effect.
exampleSentences: Small habits can make your room tidy.
Kind words can make someone smile.
Practice will make your writing stronger.
rich_json.etymology: From Old English macian, meaning to construct or prepare.

commonMistakes.whyWrong: Borrow means take temporarily; it does not mean to create an effect.
commonMistakes.correctTip: Use make with 'a difference', 'a plan', or 'a change'.
